I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During consultations for the country partnership strategy 2009–2013, held in August 
2008, the Government of Mongolia asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for technical 
assistance (TA) to develop a policy and mechanism to reduce air pollution in Ulaanbaatar. 
ADB conducted a fact-finding mission in July 2009 and reached an understanding with the 
Ministry of Mineral Resources and Energy (MMRE) and Municipality of Ulaanbaatar (MUB) 
on the TA’s objective, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, implementation arrangements, 
and consultants' terms of reference.1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Air pollution is becoming a serious problem in Ulaanbaatar. Measured in terms of 
particulate  matter  (PM),  it  is  estimated  as  several  times  above  maximum  acceptable 
standards. From 17 to 22 November 2008 the maximum daily concentration of PM with 
diameter less than 10 microns (PM ) was 600 microgram per cubic meter (µg/m3) and 
10
maximum hourly concentrations exceeded 2,500 µg/m3; maximum daily concentration of PM 
with  diameter  less  than  2.5  microns  (PM )  was  350  µg/m3  with  maximum  hourly 
2.5
concentrations exceeding 1,300 µg/m3. The Mongolian country standard is an average daily 
concentration of 50 µg/m3 for PM  and 100 µg/m3 for PM . Initial estimates suggest that 
2.5 10
total health costs range from 1% to 4% of Mongolia’s total gross domestic product.  
 
3.  Preliminary  results  of  a  World  Bank  air  pollution  monitoring  and  health  impact 
baseline study indicate that heating (and cooking) stoves used by mostly poor peri-urban 
households contribute an average of 45%–70% of the PM  concentrations. The impact of 
2.5
stove emissions from ger areas depends on location and season. Their contribution is 
highest during the winter, when coal is burned continuously, reaching 70% and more in ger 
areas and up to 60% in the city center. Other sources of pollution include dust, coal-fired 
heat-only boilers (HOB),2 coal-fired combined heat and power plant emissions, and ash 
storage. All coal combustion emits sulfur dioxide, but poor combustion results in higher 
hydrogen sulfide, which poses a more serious health risk than sulfur dioxide. 
 
4.  The government has demonstrated its commitment to the reduction of air pollution 
through  the  formation  of  the  National  Committee  on  Coordination,  Management,  and 
Oversight of Activities of Government Agencies for implementation of the government policy 
on air pollution reduction (NCC) under MMRE. The government established the NCC in late 
2008  to  overcome  slow  progress  in  addressing  air  pollution  problems  in  Mongolia, 
particularly  in  Ulaanbaatar.  The  NCC  is  mandated  to  address  air  pollution  issues  in 
Ulaanbaatar in close collaboration with MUB, develop a policy for air pollution reduction, and 
coordinate investments. The NCC includes stakeholders from a range of public and civil 
organizations.  It  is  overseeing  the  development  of  a  mechanism  to  achieve  sustained 
reductions in emissions, especially during the winter when they are severe due to use of 
rudimentary lignite-fired household stoves by about 40% of Ulaanbaatar’s population. 
 
5.  The TA is part of a multi-development partner effort involving the World Bank (which 
is  planning  a  $12  million  International  Development  Association  credit  for  air  pollution 
reduction  in  Ulaanbaatar),  European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development 
(implementing a €350,000 TA, which started in March 2009, on fuel switching policy options 
including testing of fuel-stove combinations), Japan International Cooperation Agency (has 
initiated an emissions inventory for boilers), Government of Japan (through the World Bank 
is providing a $475,000 grant for capacity building and development of carbon financing

projects through the Ministry of Nature, Environment and Tourism), France (has concluded a 
€2  million  loan  for  air  pollution  monitoring  stations  through  the  Ministry  of  Nature, 
Environment and Tourism), German development cooperation through GTZ (has installed air 
pollution monitoring stations), World Bank, and Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC).  
 
6.  The TA will prepare a large-scale program to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and 
air pollution in Ulaanbaatar. MCC is developing an investment project to support renewable 
energy development and air pollution abatement, which would scale up stove replacement 
activities piloted under the TA to cover all of Ulaanbaatar. Implementation would begin in the 
latter half of 2010. The World Bank plans to support an investment project in 2011 that will 
scale  up  stove  replacement  activities  if  the  MCC  project  does  not  materialize.3  Close 
attention will be paid to coordination of TA activities with MCC, World Bank, and other 
development partners. 
 
7.  The TA is directly linked with the government's National Development Strategy, the 
ADB 2009–2012 country operations business plan approved on 6 October 2009,4 and 
initiating paper for the country partnership strategy (2009–2013) dated October 2008. The 
TA is consistent with the parliamentary resolution on some immediate measures to be taken 
to reduce air pollution (Resolution No. 46, 2007), which has as a goal the reduction of air 
pollution and improvement of air quality in Ulaanbaatar. The TA is consistent with the vision 
of MUB as expressed in the Ulaanbaatar city air pollution reduction master plan. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be the improved air quality in Ulaanbaatar.5 A reduction in 
concentrations of particulates, sulfur dioxide, and hydrogen sulfide, in both the peripheral ger 
areas and developed city center of Ulaanbaatar, is expected to reduce the incidence of 
respiratory disease across the city. The outcome of the TA will be the establishment of a 
coordinated program for the introduction of clean technology and alternative fuels for heating.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will assist the NCC to develop knowledge and programs needed to reduce air 
pollution in Ulaanbaatar. Specifically, it will assist the government to develop programs to 
promote adoption of more efficient stoves and replace HOBs, and will pilot the mechanism 
for replacing ger stoves. A key indicator of the TA's success is the ability of the government 
to mobilize resources for full-scale implementation of these programs.  
 
10.  The TA has three components: (i) mechanism to promote adoption of cleaner burning 
stoves for gers; (ii) program for HOB replacement; and (iii) institutional strengthening, and a 
mechanism for monitoring and evaluation.  
 
11.  The first component will (i) establish laboratory capacity for testing emissions from 
the  combustion  of  fuels  in  domestic  heating  stoves;  (ii)  assist  stove  manufacturers  to 
develop improved stove designs; (iii) develop a subsidy voucher distribution mechanism for 
households to replace their current heating stoves with cleaner models; (iv) carry out a pilot 
program to test this mechanism in one or two khoroos in a district of Ulaanbaatar (up to 
1,000 households with new equipment); and (v) prepare and deliver an associated public 
awareness building program. Implementation of the mechanism to reduce winter emissions

Consensus on final pilot design will be developed through meetings and workshops among

12.  The second component will (i) develop the criteria for, and compile a prioritized list of, 
HOBs in need of replacement; (ii) carry out a boiler replacement study, comprising the 
preparation of technical design, and prefeasibility, environmental, and other preparatory 
studies required for the replacement of around 16 small-polluting boilers in public institutions 
in Ulaanbaatar; and (iii) prepare feasibility studies for HOB replacement, finalize designs, 
and develop bidding documents based on international standards. Environmental monitoring 
requirements will be incorporated in the bidding documents. 
 
13.  The third component will (i) support the NCC to develop documentation for the 
preparation, development, and piloting of the air pollution reduction mechanism; (ii) assist 
the NCC in developing a program, including an operations manual, that would scale up 
implementation of the voucher distribution mechanism for households to replace their current 
heating stoves for cleaner models; (iii) assist the NCC in developing its capability to mobilize 
resources for the implementation of the mechanism, such as the proposed MCC Mongolia 
clean air project; (iv) develop mechanisms to enable all stakeholders to play an active role in 
TA activities; and (v) assist the NCC in managing the TA and the pilot project, and in 
regularly organizing and reporting on aid coordination meetings.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 equivalent will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund6 under the Clean Energy 
Financing Partnership Facility, and administered by ADB. The government will finance the 
remaining $50,000 equivalent through in-kind contributions. The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed  in  line  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2008,  as 
amended from time to time). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  MMRE will be the executing agency for the TA and will coordinate its activities with 
MUB. MUB will be involved in all TA components with a specific focus on HOB replacement 
and ger area emission reduction elements. It will play a leading role in TA awareness-raising 
and community participation activities. MMRE has an established project implementation unit 
for ADB-assisted projects; it will be responsible for the TA.  
 
16.  The government will form a TA steering committee chaired by the MMRE director of 
the Fuel Policy Department, and vice-chaired by the head of the Municipal Air Quality 
Agency. The steering committee will comprise representatives of the Ministry of Finance; 
MMRE; the Ministry of Nature, Environment and Tourism; and MUB. The steering committee 
will oversee TA implementation, provide guidance and direction, and facilitate coordination 
and cooperation among stakeholders. 
 
17.  The  TA  will  require  136.7  person-months  of  consulting  services,  comprising  
8.7 person-months of international and 128 person-months of national consultants to carry 
out the terms of reference outlined in Appendix 3. The consultants will be engaged as 
individuals  and  through  a  firm  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). To ensure that TA activities can begin 
during the 2009–2010 winter season, when a stove replacement mechanism will be piloted, 
two  consultants—one  national  (4  person-months)  and  one  international  (1.5  person-

months)—will be recruited as individuals to commence activities related to the establishment 
of the laboratory and stove testing. The remaining consultant inputs will be engaged as a 
firm using quality- and cost-based selection with quality-to-cost ratio of 80:20. Advance 
recruitment of consultants will be requested to ensure timely implementation. Laboratory 
equipment  will  be  procured  using  the  shopping  procedure  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Other equipment will be 
procured under the consulting contract with a firm using shopping procedure in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. All equipment to be procured under the TA will be 
turned over to MMRE and MUB after TA completion. In addition to staff participation, the 
government will provide an office with utilities and telecommunications access; materials, 
data, maps, and related documents required by the TA; and field travel of appropriate staff to 
accompany the consultants. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months commencing in December 2009 with 
expected completion by November 2011. The consultants recruited as a firm will submit an 
inception report within 4 months of TA commencement. An interim report on activities during 
the first full winter season will be submitted after 18 months. A workshop will be held with 
stakeholders from the government, MUB, and nongovernment organizations 2 months after 
commencement  of  the  TA  to  discuss  the  inception  report  and  introduce  piloting 
arrangements. Two  tripartite  meetings  will  be  held:  the  first  immediately  following  the 
stakeholder workshop, and the second following submission of the draft final report. A final 
report incorporating comments will be submitted 2 weeks after the second tripartite meeting. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $500,000  to  the 
Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Asian Clean Energy Fund 
under  the  Clean  Energy  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Ulaanbaatar  Clean  Air,  and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will help the government develop a mechanism and 
program to promote adoption of more efficient stoves and heat-only boilers (HOBs), and will 
pilot the mechanism for replacement of ger stoves. A key indicator of the TA's success will 
be  the  ability  of  the  government  to  mobilize  resources  for  full  implementation  of  the 
mechanism to replace HOBs. The TA has three components: (i) mechanism to reduce winter 
emissions in ger areas; (ii) program for HOB replacement; and (iii) institutional strengthening 
and  a  mechanism  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  (M&E).  International  and  national 
consultants will be engaged as individuals and through a firm in accordance with the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). Consultants will work closely with the Ministry of Mineral Resources and 
Energy, and with the Municipality of Ulaanbaatar during the assignment.  
 
2.  The services comprise three linked parts, elements of which can run concurrently: 
 
(i)  Part A: HOB replacement including a feasibility study for boiler replacement 
(month 4), and preparation of bidding documents (month 6);  
(ii)  Part B: development of a mechanism to reduce winter emissions in ger areas 
including  (a)  awareness  raising  campaign  (from  month  4),  (b)  subsidy 
distribution mechanism (month 5), (c) laboratory testing and certification (from 
month 2), (d) stove research and development, cost effectiveness analysis, 
and production capacity building (from month 6), (e) piloting the mechanism 
(months 5–9), and (f) reporting and project document preparation, including 
reporting to ADB (continuous); and  
(iii)  Part C: institutional strengthening, M&E mechanism including establishment 
of a coordination and management unit (month 1), development of an M&E 
system (month 2), and management of activities and reporting (continuous). 
 
3.  International experts will work jointly with Mongolian experts to carry out all aspects 
of the TA. This is anticipated to require 8.7 person-months of international and 128 person-
months of national consultants. 
 
B.  Detailed Scope of Work of International Experts 
 
1.  Part A 
 
4.  Boiler expert (international, 1.5 person-months). The specialist will have at least 8 
years of experience in designing, evaluating, and installing coal-fired heating boilers with up 
to 10 megawatt capacity; experience in Mongolia is a plus. 
 
5.  The specialist will investigate the feasibility of, and develop a plan for, replacement of 
about 16 HOBS in public institutions in ger districts. The scope of work will include the 
following: 
 
(i)   Develop the criteria for and compile a prioritized list of HOBs in need of boiler 
switch-outs.  The  Ministry  of  Nature,  Environment  and  Tourism  has 
commissioned a study on all HOBs in Ulaanbaatar, their overall technical 
condition,  and  type  of  ownership.  In  addition,  in  March  2009  Japan 
International  Cooperation  Agency,  in  collaboration  with  the  Heating 
Department  of  the  Mongolia  University  of  Science  and  Technology, 
completed a rapid emissions inventory of existing HOBs. The prioritized list 
will be based on this available information.

(ii)   Carry out a boiler replacement study comprising the preparation of technical 
design, prefeasibility, environmental, and other preparatory studies required 
to replace about 16 small polluting boilers in public institutions in Ulaanbaatar. 
This includes proposals for disposing of old boilers so that they cannot be 
used again.  
 
6.  Economist in small industrial heating boiler issues (international, 2.2 person-
months). The specialist will have at least 8 years of experience to conduct prefeasibility and 
feasibility  studies  and  procurement  of  heating  boilers  with  up  to  10  megawatt  thermal 
capacity. Experience in Mongolia is a plus. The specialist is required to prepare bidding 
documents for the replacement of about 16 HOBs in public institutions in ger districts. The 
scope of work includes the following: 
 
(i)   Finalize the feasibility studies prepared by the technical specialist (including 
financial and economic analyses in accordance with recognized international 
standards),  and  develop  the  bidding  documents  based  on  international 
standards to the point that they can be launched for international tendering.  
(ii)   In discussion with the government, determine whether implementation should 
take place under an investment project or through carbon offset projects. 
Proper environmental monitoring requirements must be incorporated as an 
integral part of the bidding documents. 
(iii)   Act as team leader for the HOB component. 
 
2.  Parts B and C 
 
7.  Stove and laboratory specialist (individual) (international, 1.5 person-months). The 
specialist will have 10 years experience with stove design, production, and testing, and has 
been  actively  involved  in  particulate  matter  emission  measurements  and  setting  up  a 
laboratory  for  such  testing.  Stove  experience  in  Mongolia  is  a  necessary  requirement. 
Working closely with the ger heating specialist and economist, the executing agency, project 
implementation agency, and ADB project officer, the stove and laboratory specialist will help 
establish the testing laboratory and commence testing.  
 
8.  The specialist has two specific tasks: to set up the emission testing laboratory and 
ensure that equipment can be used; and start a program to develop cleaner stoves. Testing 
is necessary for (i) certification of stove models that will be eligible for vouchers and/or 
subsidy (near future); and (ii) development of new stove models with lower emissions that 
are better adapted to use new fuels that are likely to become available (immediately). The 
main tasks include the following: 
 
(i)   Laboratory  establishment:  (a) work with the laboratory selected for the 
testing of new stove models and assist in specifying, acquiring, and installing 
the  necessary  equipment;  (b)  operationalize  testing  procedures  and  start 
testing; tests should be according to a standard testing protocol such as 
proposed in the Ger Heating Report (to be published, Asia Sustainable and 
Alternative  Energy  Program  (World  Bank);  (c)  define  minimum  operating 
standards for environmental performance of fuel-stove combinations; and (d) 
develop a mechanism for reporting test results so that these remain available 
for future reference. 
 
  (ii)  Stove development: (a) work with interested stove and equipment producers 
and designers to develop and finalize new; (b) develop and carry out a 2-
week training session for selected and interested stove manufacturers; and (c) 
liaise with laboratory experts for the testing and certification of new models; 
ensure that developed stoves are tested, and if necessary, certified.

development  is  a  plus.  The  specialist  will  act  as  team  leader  among  the  international 
specialists working on the ger heating pilot program, and report the combined results to the 
National  Committee  on  Coordination,  Management  and  Oversight  of  Activities  of 
Government Agencies to implement government policy on air pollution reduction (NCC) and 
ADB. Other main tasks include the following: 
 
(i)   Based on the results of the ger heating program team activities, develop a 
program expansion plan that will form the basis for the Ulaanbaatar clean air 
program, a follow-on project expected to be financed by the World Bank.  
(ii)  Assist  the  NCC  in  developing  necessary  documentation  for  preparation, 
development, and roll-out of the air pollution reduction mechanism. 
(iii)   Prepare a time-bound and agency-specific operations manual for all activities 
and inputs required for the expansion and implementation of the program to 
cover the entire city. 
(iv)  Provide guidance to the international and national consultants as necessary. 
(v)   Report on a regular basis to the NCC and ADB. 
 
10.  Stove and laboratory specialist (international, 1 person-month). The specialist will 
have 10 years of experience with stove design, production, and testing, and has been 
actively involved in particulate matter mission measurements and setting up a laboratory for 
such testing. Experiences with stoves in Mongolia is required.  
 
11.  The  specialist  will  continue  to  develop  a  program,  started  with  input  from  the 
individual stove and laboratory specialist, to develop cleaner stoves. Testing is necessary for 
(i) certification of stove models that will be eligible for vouchers and/or subsidy (near future); 
and (ii) development of new stove models with lower emissions that are better adapted to 
use new fuels that are likely to become available (immediately). The main tasks include the 
following: 
 
  (i)   Laboratory  establishment:  (a)  define  minimum  operating  standards  for 
environmental  performance  of  fuel-stove  combinations;  (b)  develop  a 
mechanism for reporting test results so that these remain available for future 
reference; (c) organize a workshop to explain procedures for testing and 
certification;  and  (d)  discuss  and  propose  a  certification  mechanism  in 
conjunction  with  the  State  Inspection  Agency  and  Mongolian  Agency  for 
Standards and Metronomy.  
 
  (ii)  Stove development: (a) work with interested stove and equipment producers 
and designers in developing and finalizing new models, using a hands-on 
approach; (b) carry out follow up training for selected and interested stove 
manufacturers; and (c) liaise with the laboratory experts for the testing and 
certification of new models and make sure that developed stoves are tested, 
and if necessary, certified.  
 
12.  Microfinance  and  financing  mechanism  specialist  (international,  1.5  person-
months). The specialist will have at least 8 years experience in the development of voucher 
programs or other programs for distribution of subsidies to poor households; experience in 
Mongolia is a plus. The specialist will undertake the following:  
 
(i)   Select a district in which the governor actively supports air pollution reduction

activities.  
(ii)   Develop and test a voucher distribution mechanism.  
(iii)   Develop an awareness campaign focusing on one or two khoroos where a 
pilot program will take place. 
 
13.  To promote switching to cleaner heating systems, the subsidy mechanism could  
(i) distribute vouchers directly to households; or (ii) distribute subsidies on an output-based 
model to certified stove producers as was done under the previous Household Heating 
Stove Project (funded by the Global Environment Facility and implemented by the Ministry of 
Nature,  Environment  and  Tourism  in  cooperation  with  the  Municipality  of  Ulaanbaatar). 
Activities of the international consultant will also include the following:  
 
(i)   Review and discuss the options for a voucher mechanism and awareness 
campaign with the district and khoroo governors and stove producers, and 
develop the option that has the best chance of success.  
(ii)   Select the khoroo (one or two) for the pilot program, discuss in detail with 
local officials, and prepare for the roll out of the program together with the 
khoroo administration. 
(iii)   Together with the khoroo governors, prepare the awareness campaign and 
inform all households that a pilot will take place in their khoroo. Households 
will be asked to change their heating system (stoves and/or fuels). Inform 
them of the supporting mechanisms. During the pilot, the air quality will be 
monitored  to  document  improvements.  Each  khoroo  is  likely  to  comprise 
about 1,000 households, of which about half have a heating wall or low 
pressure boiler and may decide not to change their heating system (opting to 
switch fuel instead). For the remaining households with traditional stoves, an 
effort will be made to convince them to change their heating systems (during 
a pilot project). An expansion and replication plan will be duly written up and 
included in the operations manual.  
(iv)   Develop  a  verification  system  to  ensure  that  vouchers  and/or  producer 
subsidy are used correctly, including (a) identify checks and balances for 
verification measures, and prepare a write up of the whole mechanism for 
inclusion in the operations manual; and (b) identify and develop additional 
measures needed to collect old stoves.  
(v)   In the time before the pilot starts, prepare an informal report on how many 
households intend to change their heating system and what changes they 
intend to make. Support for ger heating system changes is likely to be offered 
through (a) the subsidy voucher and (b) the possibility to obtain a bank loan 
from Xac or Khaan Bank. The specialist will discuss with interested banks 
ways to assist ger district households financially, and additional measures to 
provide (additional) loan financing for heating solutions. 
(vi)   Help  the  national  consultant  responsible  for  implementing  the  awareness 
campaign over 3 months to develop the program and discuss this with the 
governors, and liaise as necessary with the specialists working on the other 
components. The governors of the participating khoroos will be requested to 
keep a list of households willing to change their heating system and of the 
number that would like further financial assistance, beyond the voucher.

specialist will have at least 10 years of experience in ger area development and/or heating 
issues. Working closely with the international stove and laboratory specialist, executing 
agency, project implementation unit, and ADB project officer, the specialist will help establish 
the testing laboratory and commence testing.
